I'll go through each row one by one:

Row 1: Team Ciudad Juárez. Outgoing manager Sergio Ordúña was sacked on Aug 18, 2008. Incoming manager Héctor Eugui was hired on Aug 19, 2008. No Miguel Brindisi here.

Row 2: Team UAG. José Trejo was sacked on Sep 1, 2008. Incoming manager Miguel Herrera was hired on Sep 2, 2008. Again, no Miguel Brindisi.

Row 3: Team Atlas. Outgoing manager Miguel Brindisi resigned on Sep 4, 2008. Incoming manager Darío Franco started on Sep 5, 2008. Wait, here's Miguel Brindisi as the outgoing manager, but the claim is about an incoming manager. So this row doesn't directly support the claim, but it's related.

Row 4: Puebla. José Sánchez was sacked on Sep 17, 2008. Incoming manager Mario Carrillo was hired the same day. No Miguel Brindisi here.

Row 5: Chiapas. Sergio Almaguer was sacked on Oct 1, 2008. Francisco Avilán was hired that day as well. Not relevant.

Row 6: Necaxa. Salvador Reyes was sacked on Oct 13, 2008. Incoming manager Octavio Becerril started on Oct 14, 2008. No Miguel Brindisi here either.

Now, focusing on the claim again, it's about an incoming manager named Miguel Brindisi being hired on Sep 5, 2008. From Row 3, Miguel Brindisi was the outgoing manager, and the incoming manager was Darío Franco. So the incoming manager in this case is not Miguel Brindisi but someone else.

Therefore, there is no row where Miguel Brindisi is listed as an incoming manager on Sep 5, 2008. The claim doesn't match any of the table's data because in Row 3, he was the outgoing manager, not the incoming one. So the claim is FALSE.
</think>

The claim states that Miguel Brindisi was hired as an incoming manager on September 5, 2008. However, according to the table, Miguel Brindisi was the outgoing manager of Atlas who resigned on September 4, 2008, and his replacement Darío Franco started on the following day. Since there's no row where Miguel Brindisi is listed as an incoming manager on Sep 5, the claim is FALSE.
